channel.title: NodeConf EU Badge
channel.description: Recent content on NodeConf EU Badge

item.title: Hello World on screen
item.description: Challenge 1 Display “Hello World” on the badge’s display

item.title: Unlocking Your Badge
item.description: There’s a lot more to your badge’s software than you realise. Try this: Up Up Down Down Left Right Left Right B A (Yup the Konami code!)

item.title: Built-in Software
item.description: Now that you’ve unlocked the badge (you’ll have to do this any time you remove the battery), you can explore the built in sample apps. Out of the box, your badge has the following: Your name pre-flashed into the firmware Image display cycling Selectable menus T-Rex who has escaped the Chrome browser Flappy Bird The world’s most awkward on-board REPL Etch-a-sketch Source code for all of these is of course in the Github Repo.

item.title: Detect Button Press
item.description: Challenge 2 Detect the various buttons being pressed/released on the badge.

item.title: Detect Capacitive Touch
item.description: Challenge 3 Detect the application and removal of your hand from the capacative sensors on the corners of the badge.

item.title: Flash LEDs
item.description: Challenge 4 Add some LEDs to the corners of the badge and make them flash.

item.title: Connecting to the Badge
item.description: Any modern computer with Bluetooth 4+ should be able to connect to the badge as follows: Make your badge connectable Enter the Konami code, if you haven’t already: Up, Up, Down, Down, Left, Right, Left, Right, B, A. Select “Make badge connectable” in the menu Note the Badge ID Mac Web Bluetooth on Chrome should just work if your Chrome is up to date. So simply go to the Web IDE here.

item.title: Play Music with Buzzer
item.description: Challenge 5 Solder a buzzer to one of the pins and ground and then play some tunes out on it.

item.title: Hello World on the Console
item.description: Of course we start with Hello World. Follow the connection instructions, then click on the left hand side of the IDE and type: console.log("Hello World"); Now stop and think for a minute about what just happened there in terms of communications flow.

item.title: On-Screen Menu
item.description: Challenge 6 Implement an on-screen menu with up-down-left-right-select.

item.title: Other Code Samples
item.description: There are three places you can find code to learn from and use: The Badge repo The main Espruino site The Puck.js area of the Espruino site Badge Repo Code The pre-installed main.js code is a treasure trove of useful snippets. Note however that it’s too big to be uploaded in its entirety via the Web IDE. Pre-installed badge code Games Relive your original Gameboy, Nokia and video arcade days with the following games :-)

item.title: Broadcast NFC URL
item.description: Challenge 7 Setup NFC and broadcast a different URL to the one built-into your badge. Prove it works using an Android phone.

item.title: Accessing Hardware Features
item.description: This is an Open Source Hardware project. Schematics and board design files are available in the /hardware directory of the repo. The badge uses the same core module as the Puck.js and can run most of the same software. Hardware Features include: nRF52832 SoC - 64MHz ARM Cortex M4, 64kB RAM, 512kB Flash, running the Espruino stack Bluetooth Low Energy Powered by a CR2032 battery which can last up to a week depending on what code you are running Daylight-readable LCD screen 6 input buttons Capacative touch sensors on all 6 corners Prototyping area with 8 CPU pins accessible Holes for LEDs on all 6 corners NFC antenna SWD programming pins CPU Pins (Vertical line of holes along left hand edge of badge) You write to or read from a pin with:

item.title: Broadcast Beacons
item.description: Challenge 8 Broadcast a URL using Eddystone and/or iBeacon and pick it up on your phone (Android for Eddystone, iPhone for iBeacon).

item.title: Using the prototyping area
item.description: You can add whatever hardware you like to the prototyping area. It’s where you’ll be connecting extra LEDs, buzzers etc. The column of holes along the board’s left edge are connected to pins D0 to D8, Ground and Power. However all of the other holes are unconnected and can be used to attach your components together. As always, the Espruino web-site has lots more info and examples. item.title: Use Noble on Laptop
item.description: Challenge 9 Use the Node.js Bluetooth library Noble on your laptop to read the beacon data that you are transmitting from the earlier challenge.

item.title: Use Badge for HID
item.description: Challenge 10 Turn the badge into a HID button for your laptop and use it as a clicker for your talk at NodeConf!

item.title: Connect to BLE Lightbulb
item.description: Challenge 11 See if you can connect the Badge to the BLE Lightbulb on the table in the hacking lounge and change its colours.

item.title: Connect to BLE LED Strip
item.description: Challenge 12 See if you can connect the Badge to the BLE LED Strip on the table in the hacking lounge and change its colours.

item.title: Communicate with another Badge
item.description: Challenge 13 Setup some sort of two way BLE commuication with someone else’s badge. Work as a team.

item.title: Record and Playback Sound
item.description: Challenge 14 Record sound using the “buzzer” and play it back.

item.title: Display an Image
item.description: Challenge 15 Take a PNG. Convert it to the correct format and display it on the badge.

item.title: Create a Web Bluetooth Page
item.description: Challenge 16 Implement Web Bluetooth with the Puck.js library. Make a webpage that got your last tweet from Twitter and then display it on the badge screen.

item.title: Detect a Person with a PIR Sensor
item.description: Challenge 17 Detect person/heat/movement with a PIR sensor.

item.title: Communicate with another Device
item.description: Challenge 18 If you can get your hands on some other BLE device like a Garmin, Fitbit or Milestone, see if you can figure out the protocol.
